questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the treatment for malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia, but it is to be reconstituted with sterile distilled water and not saline as it can precipitate in saline or other salt solutions.

It is given at a dose of 2.5 mg/ kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes (up to 10 mg/kg)  until the attack subsides.

All anesthetic agents should be cut off and the patient is given 100% oxygen.

Bicarbonate at a dose of 1 to 4 mEq/kg IV can be used to treat metabolic acidosis.

If the body temperature is high, it should be brought down using cold intravenous fluids, cooling body cavities with sterile iced fluids, surface cooling with ice packs and cooling blankets.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever for 1 week, with abdominal distension, loss of appetite and lymphadenopathy. There is a poor response to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is negative but  rk39 is positive. Which drug can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient should be managed with liposomal amphotericin B.

This is a case of visceral leishmaniasis, and it presents with fever associated with rigor and chills. Splenomegaly and hepatomegaly are common. Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, but in the Indian subcontinent, it is rare. 

Diagnosis is by ELISA and the indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT) and rk39 which detects antibodies to Leishmania donovani. 

Medical Therapy :

In most endemic regions (except in India and Mediterranian countries):

  • Pentavalent antimonial is the drug of choice (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate)
  • If initial pentavalent antimonial fails, then amphotericin B (AmB) is used.

In India and Mediterranian countries:

  • Liposomal AmB is the drug of choice.

Other drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis include: paromomycin and miltefosine.

Other options:

Option b: Fluconazole is an antifungal and is not useful in visceral leishmaniasis

Option c: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA  and related infections.

Option d: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

questions.text: The first line therapy for ovarian induction in PCOS patients is:
questions.solution:
For women with polycystic ovary syndrome, letrozole should be considered first-line therapy for ovulation induction because of the increased live birth rate compared with clomiphene citrate.

Recent Update: Letrozole was shown to have a higher pregnancy rate than clomiphene citrate. However, until recent times (ACOG June 2018 Interim update) it was not used for the same, because of the high risk of congenital cardiac and bone malformations.

Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It acts on ER receptors at the level of the hypothalamus and inhibits estrogenic negative feedback resulting in increased pulsatile GnRH secretion and subsequent release of FSH and LH. It has antiestrogenic action when endogenous estrogen levels are high (partial agonist).

Recombinant hCG has LH activity and is used in patients with hypogonadotropic amenorrhoea.

Metformin is an insulin sensitizer used in the treatment of Polycystic ovarian syndrome. Since hyperinsulinemia plays a pivotal pathogenic role in the development of PCOS, there is an increased frequency of spontaneous ovulation and regularization of menstrual cycles.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs will you administer to a patient having the following ECG:
questions.solution:
The ECG depicts severe hypokalemia with prominent U waves in Leads II, III, and V4–V6 and ventricular repolarization prolongation. The treatment of hypokalemia is to replenish potassium by administering oral/IV KCl.

Insulin is used to treated hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A morbidly obese, diabetic woman did not respond well to metformin therapy. She has a history of pancreatitis and a family history of bladder cancer. The patient does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.solution:
The most suitable drug to reduce this patient's blood glucose level is canagliflozin.

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor. Other SGLT-2 inhibitors include dapagliflozin and empagliflozin. They act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a change in the renal threshold. This results in a decrease in blood glucose levels. 

The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. There is a risk of the development of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis. It increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D. 

Other options:

Option A: Liraglutide (GLP-1 agonist) cannot be used as it is can be given only parenterally and the patient insists on taking medications via the non-parenteral route.

Option B: Sitagliptin cannot be given since the drug increases the risk of fatal and non-fatal pancreatitis. The patient is already suffering from pancreatitis.

Option D: Pioglitazone is associated with bladder cancer. The patient has a family history of bladder cancer.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents at the local clinic complaining of abdominal cramps, sweating, runny nose, vomiting, and muscle aches. Examination shows that his pulse is rapid and pupils are dilated. He states that he "feels just awful" and that he has had these symptoms for about 24 hours. The most likely pharmacologic treatment would be:
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms are suggestive of opioid withdrawal and clonidine is the drug of choice.

Opiate withdrawal symptoms of irritability, anxiety, sweating, sniffling, rhinorrhea, nausea, diarrhea, lacrimation, abdominal pain, headache, muscular pain, and insomnia. During withdrawal, neural activity in the Locus coeruleus (high norepinephrine content) is greatly increased, and this surge is thought to be responsible for many of the symptoms seen during withdrawal.

Clonidine is an α2-adrenergic (presynaptic) agonist. Clonidine activates presynaptic autoreceptors in the locus coeruleus to reduce norepinephrine release and turnover in the cerebral cortex. It thus decreases these symptoms by counteracting catecholamine release and decreasing the sympathetic hyperactivity in opiate withdrawal.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and left-sided limb weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and her CT appears normal. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient. Intravenous thrombolysis(alteplase 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period i.e., within 3-4.5 hours of symptom onset.

Aspirin + clopidogrel(Option B) is used in secondary prevention of stroke and also to prevent stroke following TIA.

Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) refer to episodes of stroke symptoms that have a brief duration, the standard definition of duration is <24 h, but most TIAs last <1 hr. TIAs may arise from emboli to the brain or from in situ thrombosis of an intracranial vessel. With a TIA, the occluded blood vessel reopens and neurologic function is restored. If a relevant brain infarction is identified on brain imaging, the clinical entity is now classified as stroke regardless of the duration of symptoms.

The risk of stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is approximately 10-15% in the first three months, majorly in the first two days. A reliable estimation of this risk can be obtained using the ABCD2 score. 

Other options: 

Option A: If CT is normal it only rules out hemorrhagic stroke and changes of ischemic stroke usually take time to appear on NCCT.

Option D: BP control is done when BP exceeds 220/120 mmHg, if there is malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg and thrombolytic therapy is anticipated. 

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for cyanide toxicity?
questions.solution:
Hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulfate are the preferred antidotes in cyanide toxicity.

  • If hydroxocobalamin is available,  give hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulfate. 
  • If hydroxocobalamin is not available, give amyl nitrite and sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate. Avoid nitrites if the patient has contraindications to nitrites.

Hydroxocobalamin is preferred over sodium nitrite as it does not interfere with the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. Also, sodium nitrite can induce fatal methemoglobinemia in patients who are critically ill from another cause.

Mechanism of action of antidotes:

Mechanism of antidote   Example
Binding of cyanide Direct binding of cyanide, followed by clearance Hydroxocobalamin
Induction of methemoglobinemia When cyanide binds methemoglobin, a relatively less toxic cyanomethemoglobin is formed

Sodium nitrite

Amyl nitrite
Use of sulfur donors This involves maximizing the availability of sulfur donors for rhodanese, a ubiquitous enzyme that detoxifies cyanide by transforming it to thiocyanate Sodium thiosulfate

Dicobalt EDTA can also bind cyanide, but it causes severe side effects.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is posted for inguinal hernia surgery. In order to perform a fast-track surgical procedure, the anesthetic technique of choice is:
questions.solution:
Infiltration anesthesia is ideal to perform inguinal hernia repair as a fast-track procedure.

It has a lesser incidence of complications than regional or general anesthesia. Other anesthetic techniques for hernia repair include intercostal block and ilioinguinal nerve block.

Ambulatory/Outpatient anesthesia employs the use of fast - Track surgical techniques to provide adequate surgical anesthesia and minimize post-operative complications in order to reduce the duration of hospital stay.

Disadvantage of infiltration anesthesia - Short duration of anesthesia even when long-acting local anesthetics like bupivacaine are used. Extended- duration local anesthesia can be produced by encapsulating bupivacaine into a biodegradable carrier.

Regional anesthesia is contraindicated in patients with bleeding disorders, those on anticoagulants and with local infections.

Spinal anesthesia has the disadvantage over epidural anesthesia of delayed recovery due to profound motor blockade. Spinal opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil are added to prolong postoperative analgesia and minimize motor block without delaying recovery. But the adverse effects of spinal opioids like nausea, pruritus and postoperative urinary retention are additive.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with chills and cyclical fever with sweats. She is diagnosed with P. falciparum malaria infection. Which of the following regimens will you prescribe her?
questions.solution:
A 28 week pregnant female suffering from falciparum malaria should be treated with Artemesinin based combination therapy.

Treatment of malaria in pregnancy:

  • 2nd and 3rd trimester: ACT is preferred as quinine can cause increased risk of hypoglycemia.
  • 1st trimester: Drug of choice for falciparum malaria during 1st trimester of pregnancy is quinine combined with clindamycin for 7 days. Artemisinin based combination therapy (ACT) is not recommended during 1st trimester of pregnancy because of lack of safety data.

Doxycycline is not indicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought with complaints of premature development of breast buds. The sagittal MRI of the brain revealed a hypothalamic hamartoma. All of the following are used in the treatment of this patient, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central precocious puberty. GnRH antagonists are not used in the treatment of this patient.

Precocious puberty is defined as the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years in girls.

There are two types of precocious puberty:

  • Central/GnRH-dependent precocious puberty
  • Peripheral/GnRH-independent precocious puberty

Hypothalamic hamartomas are a neuronal migration defect that is the common cause of organic central precocious puberty. These lesions are believed to cause precocious puberty through the endogenous pulsatile release of GnRH, either independently or in concert with the GnRH-secreting neurons of the hypothalamus. 

Treatment of central precocious puberty:

  • GnRH agonists (depot-forms or implants) are the treatment of choice for tumor-induced central precocious puberty.
  • Inj. depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) 100–200 mg, IM every 2–4 weeks to induce regression of these premature changes and cessation of menstruation.
  • Cyproterone acetate exerts antiandrogenic and antigonadotropin effects and is effective in treatment.
  • In patients with hypothalamic hamartoma and associated intractable gelastic or psychomotor seizures, stereotactic radiation therapy (gamma knife surgery) is more effective and has fewer risks than neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for scabies is _______
questions.solution:
Permethrin cream (5%) is the treatment of choice for scabies. It is rinsed off after 8-12 hours. It is safe and well-tolerated but often requires a second application after one week.

Benzyl benzoate (25%) ointment requires to be rinsed off after 24 hours and is contraindicated in pregnant women and children.

Crotamiton (10%) ointment is often used on scabies nodules in children but has questionable efficacy.

Malathion is not used for the treatment of scabies however it may be used to treat lice infestation.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for inverse glaucoma?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for inverse glaucoma is atropine.

Inverse glaucoma is a type of secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by the flow of aqueous humour posteriorly to the posterior segment instead of the posterior chamber. The increased pressure in the posterior segment pushes the lens forward leading to the shallowing of the anterior chamber.

Miotics are contraindicated as they can cause the ciliary zonules to slack, the lens to move forward and further shallowing of the anterior chamber. So mydriatic and cycloplegic agents such as atropine are administered.

Inverse glaucoma is also called:

  • Malignant glaucoma
  • Ciliary block glaucoma
  • Aqueous misdirection.

Note:

Pilocarpine is the drug of choice in angle-closure glaucoma but is contraindicated in inverse glaucoma.

Whereas, atropine is the drug of choice in inverse glaucoma but is contraindicated in angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with history of schizophrenia comes to psychiatry OPD with symptoms of immobility, mutism, waxy flexibility and posturing. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of schizophrenia, mutism, and posturing are suggestive of catatonia for which benzodiazepine is the treatment of choice.

It is a syndrome of marked psychomotor disturbance that occurs in severely ill patients with psychotic disorders and medical conditions (infectious, metabolic, neurologic, and rheumatologic).

Lorazepam challenge test (IV 1-2 mg) resulting in partial, temporary relief within 5-10 minutes confirms the diagnosis.

ECT is recommended in urgent clinical situations or when the patient responds poorly to benzodiazepines.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient complains of palpitations. He is hemodynamically stable. An ECG is obtained and is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows wide complex tachycardia (QRS complexes are >120 ms in duration), with regular QRS complexes with uniform morphology in each lead. This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). Since this patient is hemodynamically stable, the best management is IV amiodarone. 

In patients with sustained VT who are hemodynamically stable, medical treatment with intravenous amiodarone is preferred. Alternative drugs that can be given are lignocaine and procainamide. However, if the VT fails to resolve with medical management or if the patient's symptoms worsen, DC cardioversion is the next step. 

Other options:

Option A: Carotid massage has no role in the management of VT. It is used as an initial step in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia to block the AV node and terminate the arrhythmia.

Option B: Chest compressions are done until the defibrillator is arranged to ensure some amount of cardiac output even during this period.

Option C: If a patient with VT has hemodynamic compromise due to hypotension or impaired consciousness or has pulmonary, electrical cardioversion is performed.

questions.text:
A 7 year old boy was brought to hospital with complaints of day dreaming and a decline in school performance. His EEG was done which showed generalized 3 Hz spike wave activity occurring synchronously over both hemispheres as seen below:
Horizontal calibration : 1 sec
True statement is ___________

choices.text: Associated with head drop during seizure

questions.solution:
The 3 Hz spike and wave pattern given in the image above is characteristic of typical absence seizures. 

Drug of choice for simple childhood absence seizures is ethosuximide.

Absence seizures Atypical absence seizure
  • No change in body tone
  • Change in the tone of head and body
  • Precipitated by hyperventilation
  • Precipitated by drowsiness
  • 3Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG
  • 1-2 Hz spike and slow-wave pattern of EEG
  • Usually not associated with other syndromes
  • Associated with Lennox -Gestaut syndrome  

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome: (Option D)

  • Typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years.
  • Consists of a triad of
    • Developmental delay
    • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
    • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness
  • Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with acne conglobata. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Acne conglobata is a severe form of nodulocystic acne and isotretinoin is the treatment of choice. 

Acne conglobata typically presents with tender, disfiguring, interconnecting comedones, cysts, inflammatory nodules, and deep burrowing abscesses which may be located on the face, torso, or limbs.

Acne Treatment :

  • Elimination of comedones by normalization of follicular keratinization,
  • Decreasing sebaceous gland activity,
  • Decreasing the population of P. acnes, and decreasing inflammation.

Minimal to moderate

  • Adequately to local therapy alone.
  • Topical agents such as retinoic acid, benzoyl peroxide, or salicylic acid.
  • Topical antibacterial agents such as azelaic acid, topical erythromycin, or clindamycin.

Moderate to severe acne

  • Systemic therapy, such as doxycycline, 100 mg bid.
  • Minocycline is also useful.

Severe nodulocystic acne

  • Synthetic retinoid isotretinoin. 
  • Severe adverse events such as teratogenicity.
  • In addition, patients receiving this medication develop extremely dry skin and cheilitis and must be followed for the development of hypertriglyceridemia.
  • Recently, there have also been concerns that isotretinoin is associated with severe depression in some patients.

Related Pearl: Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Image: Global Alliance Algorithm for Improving Outcomes in acne

BPO - Benzoyl peroxide

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding alopecia areata is incorrect?

choices.text: It is characterized by the presence of exclamation mark hair
Alopecia universalis means loss of all of the body hair
Ophiasis is a pattern of loss of hair along the back of scalp
Oral corticosteroids are the initial treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Intralesional corticosteroids are the initial treatment of choice in alopecia areata. 

  • A depot steroid (hydrocortisone acetate 25 mg/mL or triamcinolone acetonide 5–10 mg/mL), administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis or by a needleless device, will stimulate hair growth at the site of injection.
  • Oral corticosteroids are used if initial treatment fails.

Other options:

Option A: The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia, which has short extractable broken hairs called exclamation mark hair, as shown in the image below.

 

Option B: Alopecia totalis means loss of all scalp hair and alopecia universalis means loss of all body hair.

The image below shows alopecia totalis with few eyebrows, eyelashes, and axillary hair, respectively.

 

 

Option C: Ophiasis is a pattern of alopecia areata characterized by the extension of alopecia (loss of hair) along the back of the scalp.

questions.text: Treatment of choice in chronic phase-CML is:
questions.solution:
• Imatinib is the drug of choice in CML and in metastatic c-kit-positive GIST.
  • Nilotinib, dasatinib are other tyrosine kinase inhibitors approved for treatment of CML.

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is treated by amphotericin B. Posaconazole can also be used. However, other azoles are not effective against this fungus.

Voriconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. It can also be used for Candida species (including glabrata and krusei), Scedosporium and Fusarium.

questions.text: The treatment of choice for the initial episode of non severe Clostridium difficile colitis is :
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for the initial episode of non-severe Clostridium difficile colitis is oral fidaxomicin. 

Management of Clostridium difficile infection according to SHEA and IDSA 2021 guidelines
 Nonfulminant  disease- Initial episode  Oral fidaxomicin is preferred over oral vancomycin
 Nonfulminant  disease- recurrent episode  Oral fidaxomicin is preferred over oral vancomycin
Bezlotoxumab can be used as an adjunctive
 Fulminant disease (presence of hypotension, shock, megacolon) without ileus  Oral vancomycin plus intravenous metronidazole 
 Fulminant disease (presence of hypotension, shock, megacolon) with ileus  Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) or rectal vancomycin

Fidaxomicin is preferred over oral vancomycin because it has less relapse rates.

questions.text: A hepatitis B infected patient awaiting liver transplantation is admitted with ascites and encephalopathy. Which of the following is the drug of choice for him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of ascites and encephalopathy in a hepatitis B infected patient is suggestive of decompensated liver disease. Tenofovir is the drug of choice for decompensated cirrhosis due to hepatitis B infection.

Tenofovir is one of the first-line drugs for chronic hepatitis B infections. It is available as two prodrug formulations tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) and tenofovir alafenamide (TAF).

Option A: Interferon-alpha is one of the first-line agents in individuals with ongoing HBV-DNA replication and liver inflammation. But it is contraindicated in decompensated cirrhosis with HBV infection as they can precipitate clinical deterioration and increase the risk of bacterial infections.  

Options B and D: Lamivudine and Telbivudine are not considered first-line agents for HBV infections because of the increased frequency of resistance associated with their use.

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal itching and green frothy genital discharge. Strawberry cervix is seen on examination. What will be the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Vaginal itching and green frothy discharge in a young female with strawberry vagina points towards trichomoniasis. Metronidazole is the drug of choice for trichomoniasis.

It is is the most common parasitic infection in humans in the industrialized world.

It is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, an anaerobic, flagellated protozoa, exists only as a trophozoite (no cyst stage).

Diagnosis is made by detection of motile flagella during microscopic examination of wet mounts. Direct immunofluorescent antibody staining is more sensitive (70-90%) than wet mount.

Culture is done on Feinberg-Whittington media.

Treatment: DOC- Metronidazole 2 gm single oral dose. All sexual partners must be treated to prevent reinfection, especially from asymptomatic males. Tinidazole can also be used for the treatment of trichomoniasis.

The image below shows strawberry vagina seen in trichomoniasis:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: First line therapy in symptomatic endometriosis is __________
questions.solution:
The first line therapy in symptomatic endometriosis is NSAIDs.

NSAIDs ± Oral contraceptive pills are used as first line therapy in suspected endometriosis.

Laparoscopy is indicated in endometriosis for

  • Confirmation of diagnosis
  • No response to medical therapy
  • Treatment of infertility

Laparotomy is indicated when there are severe adhesions leading to bowel or bladder fisulas.

questions.text: You see Sanjay who is a known case of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, on steroid therapy in the ER with vomiting and fever. You administer double the regular dose of steroids. Which drug is being referred to here?
questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone, which is the mainstay treatment for commonest type of CAH, is the drug referred to in the given clinical scenario.

Double or triple doses are indicated during periods of stress, such as infection or surgery.

Glucocorticoid replacement therapy with hydrocortisone, 15-20 mg/m²/24 h, orally, in 3 divided doses is continued lifelong.

Mineralocorticoid replacement with fludrocortisone is used for patients with the salt-wasting disease. The daily dose of fludrocortisone in infants is higher than that in older children.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is commonly used for treating community-acquired pneumonia in OPD?
questions.solution:
Azithromycin is the drug of choice for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) in an OPD setup.

Outpatient management of CAP: 

1. For previously healthy patients who have not taken antibiotics within the past 3 months:

  • A macrolide – Azithromycin, 500 mg orally as a first dose and then 250 mg orally daily for 4 days, or 500 mg orally daily for 3 days, or
  • Clarithromycin, 500 mg orally twice a day; or
  • Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day

2. For patients with such comorbid medical conditions as chronic heart, lung, liver, or kidney disease, diabetes mellitus, alcoholism, malignancy, asplenia, immunosuppressant conditions or use of immunosuppressive drugs or use of antibiotics within the previous 3 months:

  • A respiratory fluoroquinolone (moxifloxacin, 400 mg orally daily; gemifloxacin, 320 mg orally daily; levofloxacin, 750 mg orally daily) or
  • A macrolide (as above) plus a beta-lactam (amoxicillin, 1 g orally three times a day; amoxicillin-clavulanate, 2 g orally twice a day; cefuroxime, 500 mg orally twice a day).

3. In regions with a high rate (> 25%) of infection with high level (MIC ≥ 16 mcg/mL) macrolide-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae, consider the use of alternative agents listed in (2) for patients with comorbidities.

Other options: Vancomycin, Ceftriaxone, and Streptomycin are administered parenterally, and hence, not appropriate for outpatient management.

Related Pearl: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for a case of scrub typhus during pregnancy is azithromycin. For other patients the drug of choice is doxycycline.

An alternative treatment option in pregnant women and patients allergic to doxycycline is chloramphenicol.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is effective in the delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Aprepitant is the drug preferred for delayed onset vomiting after cancer chemotherapy.

Nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy occur in two phases:

  • The acute phase is seen within 24 hours and occurs in almost all patients receiving chemotherapy. In response to chemotherapeutic agents, the enterochromaffin cells in the small intestine secrete serotonin, which acts on the 5HT3 receptors and causes vomiting. This phase is treated by 5HT3 antagonists such as ondansetron, granisetron, and palanosetron.
     
  • The delayed phase is seen on days 2-5 and occurs only in some patients. It occurs in response to stimulation of NK-1 receptors by substance P. 5HT3 antagonists are not effective against the delayed phase, and NK-1 receptor antagonists are used in these patients. 

NK-1 receptor antagonists include aprepitant and its parenteral formulation, fosaprepitant, rolapitant, and netupitant. These drugs are usually administered in combination with 5HT3 antagonists and dexamethasone for highly emetogenic chemotherapy. A fixed-dose combination of netupitant and palanosetron has been approved to cover both the acute and delayed phase of post-chemotherapy nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: Drug of choice for actinomycosis is:
questions.solution:
Penicillin G is the agent of choice for the treatment of all forms of actinomycosis.

The dose should be 18-24 million units of penicillin G intravenously per day for 6 weeks. Some physicians continue therapy for 2-3 months with oral penicillin V (500 mg four times daily). Surgical drainage or excision of the lesion may be necessary before a cure is accomplished.

Alternatively, treatment can also be done with tetracyclines.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with an acute onset of blurry vision in the right eye. She had a sinus infection 2 weeks ago. She further recalls that 6 years ago, she had unilateral hemibody paraesthesias for a few weeks during her school examinations. Similar symptoms get triggered when she is overly tired. What is the immediate management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with an acute relapse of multiple sclerosis and methylprednisolone is used for immediate management.

The patient’s history of multiple clinically distinct episodes of central nervous system dysfunction exaggerated during times of stress and spontaneous partial resolution of the symptoms are highly suggestive of multiple sclerosis.

The patients' symptoms of blurry vision and pain on movement of the eye are suggestive of optic neuritis.

High dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for five days without an oral taper is the drug of choice for acute exacerbation of multiple sclerosis.

Plasma exchange (Option B)can be used for an acute relapse of multiple sclerosis but is not the first preferred treatment. It can used along with steroids or in case of poor response to steroids. Beta interferon (Option C) is effective in the treatment of MS. But they are used for relapsing-remitting type MS.

Acyclovir (Option D) is not effective in the treatment of Acute MS. It can be used for the viral causes of optic neuritis.

2017 revised, McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. The McDonald’s criteria takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves an assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.

questions.text: The drug of choice in anaphylactic shock is?

choices.text: Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV

questions.solution:
Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 by intramuscular route (IM) is the drug of choice for treatment of anaphylactic shock. Hence it is the answer here.

In case the patient develops life threatening condition, adrenaline 0.25 mg IV is given.

Note : This is a controversial question. The following inference from journal may help to clarify the concept.

  • As vasodilatation is the main pathological change early in anaphylaxis, this enables the subcutaneous or intramuscular absorption of adrenaline to be rapid and effective.
  • Thus, when the disease is treated early and is progressing slowly, or venous access is difficult or the patient is unmonitored, intramuscular adrenaline has advantages in terms of safety and is usually effective.
  • Later, when intravascular volume is depleted and shock occurs with a life threatening situation, or there is severe dyspnoea or airway compromise, the intravenous route is necessary to achieve optimal absorption.

questions.text: A school teacher finds a 7 yr old child to be extremely naughty, unable to sit in a place for a long time, excessively talking, and unable to concentrate on a thing for a long time. Which of the following drug is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD). The drug of choice for ADHD is Methylphenidate.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuro­ psychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its etiology and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually rec­ognized between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may sometimes disappear, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to antisocial behavior, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists).

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behavior modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy.

Note: Modafinil is used in the management of narcolepsy.

questions.text: An asymptomatic 30-year-old man presents with a lesion on his thigh as seen in the below image. He returned a week ago from the US where he inspected farming areas during the summer. The best management for this patient would be:

choices.text: Reassurance as it is a fixed drug eruption

questions.solution:
The given image classically depicts the bull’s eye lesion (erythema chronicum migrans) and the clinical history is suggestive of the diagnosis of Lyme disease. The drug of choice for early asymptomatic Lyme disease is Doxycycline 100 mg BD.

Lyme disease is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted by the hard tick, Ixodes. It usually occurs after a tick bite while strolling through the farms. Most of them do not recall the bite and the initial presentation is only a skin lesion known as erythema chronicum migrans.

It is only after dissemination, that the disease spreads to joints (arthritis), heart (AV blocks), and the nervous system (neuroborreliosis).

The treatment protocol for early Lyme disease includes:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg BD (Drug of choice) for 2-3 weeks (or)
  • Amoxicillin 500 – 1000 mg for 2-3 weeks (for children < 9 years, pregnant women)

In severe disseminated cases, Ceftriaxone 2 g IV for 2-3 weeks can be given. 

Other options:

Option A - Chloroquine and tafenoquine are used to prevent Plasmodium vivax malaria relapse. There are no clinical symptoms suggestive of Malaria. 

Option C - Antihistamines can be used to treat urticaria. Patients present with short-lived itchy weals, angioedema, or both. 

Option D - Fixed drug eruption presents as a sharply defined oval or round erythematous, edematous plaque. It becomes dusky, violaceous, and vesicular or bullous. It occurs in the lips, genitals, palms, and soles.

questions.text: Pandu, a 24-year-old man with a history of depression is brought to the emergency department after being found confused in his garage. He has a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, elevated serum creatinine, and dumbbell-shaped crystals are seen in his urine on microscopic analysis. Ethylene glycol level is pending. Arterial pH is 7.33. Measured serum osmolality is 320 mmol; serum sodium is 140, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 28, and glucose is 180. What is the next appropriate step?

choices.text: Await ethylene glycol level before initiating therapy
Start intravenous antibiotics and obtain renal imaging to evaluate for staghorn calculi

questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from ethylene glycol (antifreeze; used in engine coolants) toxicity and hence the next step is to administer fomepizole.

Diagnosis is facilitated by high anion gap metabolic acidosis, the presence of an osmolar gap (both attributable to metabolites of ethylene glycol- oxalic acid and glycolic acid) and recognition of oxalate crystals in urine.

Here, the osmolar gap is 20 [{calculated osmolality is 2(Na)+BUN/2.8+glucose/18=300};measured osmolality- calculated osmolality= 320-300=20].

The combination of a high anion gap and a high osmolar gap in a patient suspected of ethylene glycol ingestion should be considered as a case of ethylene glycol toxicity. And treatment should not be delayed awaiting the report of ethylene glycol level in this setting.

Treatment includes prompt administration of saline or osmotic diuresis, thiamine and pyridoxine supplements, fomepizole and if needed, hemodialysis.

The IV administration of the alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, fomepizole (4-methylpyrazole; 15 mg/kg as loading dose) is the treatment of choice. IV ethanol, if used, should be infused to achieve a blood level off 22 mmol/L (100 mg/dL). Both fomepizole and ethanol reduce toxicity because they compete with ethylene glycol for metabolism by alcohol dehydrogenase.

Haemodialysis is indicated when the arterial pH is <7.3 or the osmolar gap exceeds 20 mOsm/kg.

questions.text: In an immunocompromised patient, which of the following is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of pneumocystis jirovecii?
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole Combination (commonly known as Co-trimoxazole) is the first line drug for both prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii infections in immunocompromised patients.

Cotrimoxazole acts by causing a sequential block of folate metabolism.

CD4+ T cell counts below 200 cells/μL are an indication to start prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 32 year old male presents to the clinic with the following facial lesion. Upon probing there is yellowish sulfur granular discharge. Which of the following is the drug of choice for the condition?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Cervicofacial actinomycosis.
It presents as a painless nodule that indurates with purulent discharge that contains sulphur granules.

The treatment of choice is Penicillin.

Doxycycline and clindamycin are used in case of penicillin allergy.

questions.text: As per the syndromic approach to sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and reproductive tract infections (RTIs), what is the treatment of choice of gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis?
questions.solution:
As per the syndromic approach to STIs/RTIs, the treatment of choice of for gonococcal and non-gonoccocal urethritis is azithromycin + cefixime.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for obsessive-compulsive disorder?
questions.solution:
SSRIs (Fluoxetine among given options) are the drug of choice for obsessive compulsive disorder.

Remember: Clomipramine, a relatively serotonergic tricyclic antidepressant is most effective in case of OCD.

In head-to-head comparisons of clomipramine and SSRIs, there is equal efficacy, but SSRIs are better tolerated.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in the prophylactic management of migraine?
questions.solution:
Drugs that have not shown benefit in prophylaxis of migraine: Verapamil (a calcium channel blocker), nimodipine, clonidine, fluoxetine (an SSRI).

Drugs used for prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta blockers: Propranolol, metoprolol, timolol, atenolol
  • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine
  • Anticonvulsants: Valproate, topiramate
  • Serotonin antagonist: Methysergide
  • Angiotensin II receptor blocker: Candesartan
  • Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor: Lisinopril
  • Calcium channel blockers: Flunarizine

Onabotulinum toxin type A is used in prevention of chronic migraine

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who has been on dialysis for 2 years presents with bone pain and bowing of legs. Further evaluation reveals hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia. What is the initial treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) and hyperphosphatemia in a patient with CKD. Sevelamer is the best initial treatment for this patient. It is a phosphate binder that reduces the absorption of phosphate from the gastrointestinal tract.

Other phosphate binders that can be used include:

  • Calcium containing
    • Calcium acetate
    • Calcium carbonate
  • Non-calcium containing
    • Sevelamer
    • Lanthanum

Calcitriol and cinacalcet are used to decrease PTH levels in secondary hyperparathyroidism. However, they also cause increased serum phosphate levels. Hence, they should not be given as initial treatment in patients with hyperphosphatemia.

Bisphosphonates like pamidronate are used in the treatment of primary hyperparathyroidism.

World Kidney Day is a global health event celebrated annually on the 2nd Thursday in March since 2006. This year, on March 14, the theme is "Kidney Health for All: Advancing equitable access to care and optimal medication practice." The focus is on overcoming barriers like gaps in early diagnosis, limited healthcare coverage, low awareness among healthcare workers, and challenges in medication accessibility and cost. The goal is to promote awareness about the vital role of kidneys and address issues to ensure optimal kidney care worldwide.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic was brought to casualty with a history of agitation and hallucinations since the previous day. He had his last drink three days ago. On examination, the patient has generalized tremulousness and tachycardia, and the liver markers are deranged. Which of the following drugs can be safely used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic with agitation and hallucinatory behaviours along with tremors is suggestive of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Lorazepam is the drug that this patient can use as it can be safely used for liver dysfunction.

Benzodiazepines are the mainstay of treatment of alcohol withdrawal syndrome.

Alcohol withdrawal symptoms include autonomic hyperactivity such as increased pulse rate, blood pressure, and body temperature, restlessness, disturbed sleep, anxiety, nausea, tremors and severe withdrawal involving auditory, visual, or tactile hallucinations, delirium, seizures, and coma.

These are commonly treated with benzodiazepines such as oxazepam, diazepam, chlordiazepoxide, and lorazepam. Diazepam (Option C) and chlordiazepoxide(Option B) require less frequent dosing but are not useful in the elderly or patients with hepatic dysfunction. Due to its short half-life and metabolism through glucuronidation only, lorazepam is best for the treatment of alcohol withdrawal in older adults. Lorazepam and oxazepam can also be used in patients with hepatic dysfunction.

Other options:

Option D:  Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is a serotonin-norephedrine reuptake inhibitor used in major depressive disorder. It increases appetite and causes significant weight gain.

questions.text: A patient with ruptured spleen is taken for laparotomy. His blood pressure is 80/50 and heart rate is 125/min. Induction agent of choice for this patient is:
questions.solution:
Induction doses of ketamine increase blood pressure, heart rate and cardiac output that make it useful for anesthetizing patients at risk for hypotension.

In the present case, the patient is presenting with low blood pressure, the most appropriate agent would be ketamine.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of alcoholic liver disease is being taken up for cholecystectomy. Which anesthetic agent would be ideal for this patient?
questions.solution:
The anesthetic agent that is ideal for a patient with liver disease is sevoflurane.

Sevoflurane is a fluorinated volatile anesthetic and is an ideal induction agent (has a rapid recovery profile and is not irritating to airways). 

The hepatic effects of volatile anesthetics are caused by alterations in liver perfusion. Hepatic arterial buffer response (HABR) is an autoregulatory mechanism of hepatic blood flow. When portal blood flow decreases due to decreased cardiac output or hypovolemia, the hepatic arterial blood flow increases in order to maintain total hepatic blood flow. This response is best preserved with sevoflurane and isoflurane. Thus, sevoflurane is not known to cause hepatotoxicity. 

Other options:

Option B: Halothane is a volatile anesthetic that has been used for maintenance but it can cause fulminant hepatic necrosis known as halothane hepatitis. 

Option C: Midazolam is an intravenous anesthetic. Its elimination is reduced in liver disease leading to an increased sedating effect.

Option D: Dexmedetomidine is also an intravenous anesthetic that has reduced elimination in patients with liver dysfunction.

questions.text: You are tasked with giving post-operative care to a patient who just underwent open abdominal surgery. Which of the following is the most effective treatment to prevent the patient from developing deep vein thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Heparin, especially low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is more effective for prophylaxis of DVT in patients who have undergone major surgeries where early ambulation is not possible. 

The choice of prophylaxis depends on the type of surgery, trauma, and duration of postoperative immobilisation. Major trauma, abdominal and orthopaedic surgeries warrant a longer duration of postoperative immobilisation. So, the pharmacological method is preferred in these situations.

Mechanical methods are advised in patients who are expected to be up and walking within 24 to 48 hours such as after minor trauma. The simplest method is for the patient to ambulate. The activation of the calf pump mechanism is an effective means of prophylaxis.

Additionally, compression stockings are advised. It can reduce the risk of DVT by exerting graduated pressure on the leg, with the pressure being greatest at the ankle.

Advantages of LMWH over unfractionated heparin: 

  • LMWH has a longer plasma half-life and significantly higher bioavailability.
  • The consistent bioavail­ability and clearance of LMWH do not require monitoring of aPTT or anti-factor Xa activity.
  • Dosing is merely based on the patient’s weight.
  • There is a more predictable anticoagulant response than with unfractionated heparin.

LMWH inhibits factor Xa and not IIa activity, with the ratio of anti-factor Xa to anti-factor IIa activity ranging from 1:1 to 4:1.

questions.text: An asthmatic patient complains of wheezing and shortness of breath most days of the week. Which of the following therapies is preferred in him?
questions.solution:
This patient has persistent asthma for which the preferred therapy is LABA with ICS available as a combination inhaler.

ICS should be started in any patient who needs to use a short-acting beta-2 agonist inhaler for symptomatic control more than twice a week (persistent asthma). 

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2022)

Asthma management - GINA 2022

questions.text: The most effective drug in the treatment of loa-loa is?
questions.solution:
DEC - Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice for the treatment of loiasis, but it is advisable to start with a small initial dose to diminish host reactions that result from the destruction of microfilariae.

Treatment is initiated with test doses of 50 mg (1 mg/kg in children) daily for 2–3 days, escalating to maximally tolerated daily doses of 9 mg/kg in three doses for 2–3 weeks.

Glucocorticoids pretreatment may be administered to ameliorate acute reactions. In rare instances, life-threatening encephalopathy follows the treatment of loiasis, probably due to the inflammatory reaction to dead or dying microfilariae lodged in the cerebral microvasculature.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is amiloride.

Amiloride belongs to the K+-sparing diuretic group. It is a renal epithelial Na+ channel(ENac) inhibitor in collecting duct cells. Lithium enters through the ENac and inhibits the action of the anti-diuretic hormone. Amiloride blocks the entry of Li+ ion through the ENac and thus mitigates diabetes insipidus induced by lithium.

The most important adverse effect of amiloride is hyperkalemia. Other adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and headache.

Other options:

Option A: Demeclocycline belongs to the tetracycline group of antibiotics. It interferes with the anti-diuretic hormone action but is used in the treatment of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone(SIADH). 

Option B: Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+-Cl- symport present in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It is used in the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by decreasing the ability of the kidney to excrete free water. It increases the reabsorption of water in the proximal tubule and reduces the ability of the distal tubule to dilute the urine. 

Option C: Tolvaptan is a vasopressin antagonist used in the treatment of SIADH, hypervolemic and euvolemic hyponatremia.

questions.text: The decorporation agent of choice for contamination by Uranium is:
questions.solution:
Bicarbonate is the decorporation agent of choice for internal Uranium contamination. It causes increased excretion of Uranium via the kidneys.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with 2 weeks of productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. A chest radiogram was done as shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for him?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient most likely has a lung abscess, as the chest X-ray shows an air-fluid level. Clindamycin is the drug of choice for treating lung abscesses.

Chest X-ray showing lung abscess(yellow) with air-fluid level (arrow):

Clindamycin is preferred over penicillin for primary lung abscesses (caused by aspirating oral flora in healthy individuals) due to its effectiveness against β-lactamase-producing anaerobes. Recommended treatments include IV clindamycin followed by oral clindamycin or a β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combination like amoxicillin-clavulanate. Therapy continues until imaging confirms resolution. Metronidazole alone is ineffective since it does not cover microaerophilic streptococci.

Secondary lung abscesses (caused by underlying conditions like malignancy, immunosuppression, or bronchial obstruction) are treated by targeting the identified pathogen and prolonging antibiotic courses based on the patient’s immune status. If no improvement is seen in 7 days, further evaluation is needed to rule out underlying causes.

Large abscesses (>6–8 cm) are less likely to resolve without additional interventions, such as drainage or surgery. Patients who fail antibiotic therapy, especially if they are poor surgical candidates, may require surgical resection or percutaneous drainage. Possible complications of drainage include pleural infection, pneumothorax, and hemothorax.

Note: Pneumatoceles are thin-walled cavities in the lung parenchyma that are seen in respiratory tract infections. They are most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus in children and Pneumocystis jirovecii in immunocompromised adults. Below is the chest X-ray showing a pneumatocele.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with complaints of increased sweating and weight loss over the past two months. On examination, he is tachycardic, has exophthalmos, and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland.  Which of the following is the drug of choice for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Graves disease and the drug of choice is methimazole.

Option A: Methimazole is preferred over propylthiouracil due to fewer side effects and single-daily dosing (compared to PTU which is given TID).

Option C: Levothyroxine is used in hypothyroidism.

Option D: Lugol's iodine is a thyroid hormone-release inhibitor but not used as a first-line drug.
